tasks.title: Setup Hero Component Structure and Repository Organization
tasks.description: Create the foundational component structure for the hero section redesign with proper TypeScript interfaces and folder organization
tasks.details: Create the directory structure: src/components/hero/ with HeroSection.tsx, HeroVisual.tsx, StatusBadge.tsx files. Create src/components/shared/TechTicker.tsx and src/data/hero-content.ts. Define TypeScript interfaces for hero content data structure including headline, subheadline, status, CTAs, and image paths. Setup proper imports and exports for all components.
tasks.testStrategy: Verify all files are created with correct TypeScript interfaces. Test that components can be imported without errors. Validate folder structure matches PRD specifications.

subtasks.title: Create hero and shared component directory structure
subtasks.description: Set up the required folder hierarchy and empty component/data files for the hero section foundation.
subtasks.details:
Create the following directories if they do not exist: src/components/hero/, src/components/shared/, and src/data/. Inside src/components/hero/, create HeroSection.tsx, HeroVisual.tsx, and StatusBadge.tsx as React+TypeScript component files with minimal placeholder functional components exported by default. In src/components/shared/, create TechTicker.tsx with a placeholder functional component. In src/data/, create hero-content.ts as a TypeScript module exporting placeholder hero content data. Ensure file names and paths exactly match the specification so future tasks can import them without path changes.
<info added on 2026-01-10T20:13:42.979Z>
Completed directory structure and placeholder file creation successfully. All required directories (src/components/hero/, src/components/shared/, src/data/) have been established with their respective component files. Each placeholder component follows Next.js App Router patterns with proper "use client" directives and compiles without TypeScript errors. The foundation is now ready for interface definitions and component implementation in subsequent subtasks.
</info added on 2026-01-10T20:13:42.979Z>
subtasks.testStrategy: Confirm all folders and files exist with correct names and extensions, and that the app compiles without new import or module resolution errors.

subtasks.title: Define TypeScript interfaces for hero content data
subtasks.description: Model the hero content data structure with TypeScript interfaces used by hero-content.ts and components.
subtasks.details: In src/data/hero-content.ts, define interfaces (or types) for the hero data, including at minimum: headline (string), subheadline (string), status (string or structured object if needed), ctas (array of CTA objects with label, href, optional variant), and image paths or sources (e.g., profileImageSrc, alt text). Export these interfaces so they can be reused in HeroSection.tsx and HeroVisual.tsx. Use idiomatic React+TypeScript patterns for props typing by referencing these interfaces in component props definitions where relevant.[2][6]
subtasks.testStrategy: Run TypeScript type-checking to ensure the interfaces are valid and imported correctly by any consuming components; verify hero-content.ts exports compile without errors.

subtasks.title: Implement base props types and component signatures
subtasks.description: Add strongly typed props definitions and minimal JSX structure for all hero-related components.
subtasks.details: In HeroSection.tsx, HeroVisual.tsx, StatusBadge.tsx, and TechTicker.tsx, define React.FC components with explicit props interfaces. For example, StatusBadge should accept at least a status or label prop, HeroVisual should accept image-related data typed using the hero content interfaces, and HeroSection should accept or internally import the hero content data structure. Ensure each component exports its props interface or keeps it local depending on reuse needs. Keep the JSX minimal (simple wrapper elements) while ensuring all props are correctly typed and referenced.[1][2][6]
subtasks.testStrategy: Run the TypeScript compiler and a dev build to verify that all components compile, props are correctly typed, and no implicit any or type errors occur.

subtasks.title: Wire hero-content data into HeroSection and child components
subtasks.description: Connect the hero-content.ts data to HeroSection and pass typed props to child components.
subtasks.details: In HeroSection.tsx, import the hero content object from src/data/hero-content.ts. Use the defined interfaces to type the imported data. Pass the appropriate slices of data as props into StatusBadge (e.g., status text), HeroVisual (e.g., image paths and alt text), and any CTA rendering logic, ensuring all props types align with the interfaces. Keep layout and styling minimal at this stage; focus on correct data plumbing and type safety.
subtasks.testStrategy: Render HeroSection in a test page or Storybook story and verify at runtime that placeholder data appears from hero-content.ts without TypeScript or runtime prop errors.

subtasks.title: Set up index exports and import paths for hero components
subtasks.description: Create central export files or adjust imports to ensure clean, consistent component consumption.
subtasks.details: If following an index-based pattern, add src/components/hero/index.ts exporting HeroSection, HeroVisual, and StatusBadge, and optionally an index in src/components/shared/ exporting TechTicker.[3][5] Update any existing or sample usage (e.g., main page) to import from these barrel files or consistent relative paths. Confirm there are no circular dependencies. This step finalizes repository organization for the hero module and shared ticker component.
subtasks.testStrategy: Run a full TypeScript build and application start to ensure that HeroSection and related components can be imported from their intended module paths without resolution errors, and that tree of imports is clean and compiles successfully.

tasks.title: Implement Design System Tokens and Theme Configuration
tasks.description: Configure the dark IDE precision theme with specified color palette, typography, and design tokens
tasks.details: Implement design tokens: Background #1A1A1A, Primary Accent #00D4AA (Teal), Secondary Accent #FFD700 (Gold), Text High #F8F9FA, Text Muted #CBD5E1. Configure typography with Inter/Geist for headlines (weights 700/600) and JetBrains Mono for monospace elements. Setup Tailwind CSS custom colors and font families. Create CSS custom properties for consistent theming.
tasks.testStrategy: Verify all color tokens render correctly. Test typography weights and font families display properly. Validate Tailwind custom classes work as expected.

subtasks.title: Define core color tokens and Tailwind theme colors for dark IDE palette
subtasks.description: Create a structured color token set for the dark IDE precision theme and wire it into Tailwindâ€™s theme configuration.
subtasks.details: Add a design-tokens file (e.g., tokens/colors.ts or JSON) defining semantic tokens like bg-base, accent-primary, accent-secondary, text-high, text-muted mapped to hex values: #1A1A1A, #00D4AA, #FFD700, #F8F9FA, #CBD5E1. Configure tailwind.config.js to extend theme.colors with these tokens under a clear namespace (e.g., brand, surface, text). Ensure no hard-coded hex values remain in base layout styles where tokens should be used.
subtasks.testStrategy: Use a test page or Storybook story to render sample background, buttons, and text using Tailwind classes referencing the new colors; visually confirm hex values via devtools and ensure classes build correctly.

subtasks.title: Configure typography tokens and Tailwind font families
subtasks.description: Set up typography design tokens and connect Inter/Geist and JetBrains Mono to Tailwind font families and utilities.
subtasks.details: Define typography tokens for heading and code text, including families and weights (e.g., heading-font: Inter or Geist with 700/600 weights, code-font: JetBrains Mono). Add @font-face or Next.js font loader configuration as appropriate. Extend tailwind.config.js theme.fontFamily and fontWeight to expose these as utilities (e.g., font-heading, font-mono, font-semibold, font-bold). Ensure base heading elements (h1â€“h4) and code/pre styles use the tokens rather than raw font names.
subtasks.testStrategy: Render sample headings, body text, and code blocks using Tailwind classes; inspect computed styles to confirm correct font families and weights are applied across breakpoints and browsers.

subtasks.title: Create CSS custom properties for color and typography tokens
subtasks.description: Expose the design tokens as CSS custom properties for consistent theming across non-Tailwind styles.
subtasks.details: In a global stylesheet (e.g., styles/globals.css), define :root or .theme-dark scope with CSS variables such as --bg-base, --accent-primary, --accent-secondary, --text-high, --text-muted, --font-heading, --font-mono, and any needed weight tokens. Map these variables to the same values used in Tailwind tokens to keep a single source of truth. Optionally add a .theme-light placeholder set for future modes. Ensure components that use raw CSS (not Tailwind) reference these variables.
subtasks.testStrategy: Open a sample page and inspect root element to confirm variables exist and match expected values; temporarily change a variable and verify that all dependent elements update without code changes.

subtasks.title: Wire tokens into base layout, components, and dark theme class
subtasks.description: Apply the new tokens and theme configuration to the appâ€™s base layout and key components to enforce the dark IDE theme.
subtasks.details: Update global layout or _app wrapper to set the dark theme class (e.g., <body class="theme-dark bg-bg-base text-text-high"> using Tailwind token utilities). Refactor existing components that currently use hard-coded colors or fonts so they instead use Tailwind utilities and/or CSS custom properties derived from the tokens. Ensure background, primary/secondary accents, and text styles reflect the new dark IDE precision theme consistently across Header, Hero, and common UI elements.
subtasks.testStrategy: Manually review core screens (especially hero-related components) to verify consistent dark styling; use devtools to confirm no legacy hex values or font declarations remain where tokens should be used.

subtasks.title: Validate theme configuration, build output, and regression safety
subtasks.description: Confirm the design token and theme setup works across build, runtime, and future dependent tasks.
subtasks.details: Run the build pipeline to ensure Tailwind and CSS changes compile without errors. Check the generated Tailwind CSS to confirm custom colors and fonts are included and tree-shaken appropriately. Add or update a minimal visual regression or snapshot test (e.g., Storybook stories for core primitives or a Jest/Playwright screenshot) to lock in the dark theme appearance. Document token names and usage guidelines in a short MD file for downstream tasks (HeroSection, HeroVisual, interactions, performance).
subtasks.testStrategy: Run unit/e2e or Storybook snapshot tests to detect visual regressions; verify that dependent tasks (HeroSection, HeroVisual) can consume the new tokens without additional configuration and that no runtime styling errors appear in console.

tasks.title: Build StatusBadge Component with Live Indicator
tasks.description: Create the status badge component showing current Fujifilm role with animated green dot indicator
tasks.details: Implement StatusBadge.tsx with inline-flex layout, gap-2 spacing, px-3 py-1 padding, rounded-full border, bg-white/5 background, border-white/10, text-xs font-mono styling using Primary Accent Teal (#00D4AA). Add pulsing green dot animation using CSS keyframes or Tailwind animate-pulse. Component should accept status text as prop and render the live indicator.
tasks.testStrategy: Test badge renders with correct styling and colors. Verify pulsing animation works smoothly. Test component with different status text lengths.

subtasks.title: Define StatusBadge component API and TypeScript props
subtasks.description: Specify StatusBadge.tsx location, define the props interface (e.g., status text string, optional className), and decide whether any accessibility attributes or variants are needed.
subtasks.details: Create src/components/hero/StatusBadge.tsx. Define a TypeScript interface such as `interface StatusBadgeProps { status: string; className?: string; }`. Ensure the component is a functional React component using FC or typed props. Consider adding ARIA attributes like `aria-live="polite"` if the status may change dynamically. Export the component as a named or default export consistent with the project conventions.
subtasks.testStrategy: Verify TypeScript correctly infers props, and importing StatusBadge from other files (e.g., HeroSection.tsx) produces no type errors.

subtasks.title: Implement StatusBadge layout and base styling
subtasks.description: Build the JSX structure and apply the specified Tailwind-based layout and typography styles for the status badge container and text.
subtasks.details: In StatusBadge.tsx, return a root element (e.g., `<div>`) with classes: `inline-flex items-center gap-2 px-3 py-1 rounded-full border bg-white/5 border-white/10 text-xs font-mono`. Apply text color using the Primary Accent Teal (#00D4AA), either via a Tailwind custom color class or inline style `style={{ color: '#00D4AA' }}` if custom token is not yet configured. Render the `status` prop next to the live indicator in a span. Ensure the badge visually fits the dark hero theme and respects existing design tokens if present.
subtasks.testStrategy: Render StatusBadge in a Storybook story or temporary test page and visually verify spacing, rounded border, background opacity, border opacity, font, and text color match design expectations.

subtasks.title: Create animated green live indicator dot
subtasks.description: Add the circular green dot element and implement the pulsing animation using CSS keyframes or Tailwind utilities.
subtasks.details: Inside the StatusBadge layout, render a small dot element (e.g., `<span>`) before the status text with classes like `h-2 w-2 rounded-full bg-green-400`. Implement pulsing using either Tailwind's `animate-pulse` or a custom keyframes class (e.g., `.live-dot` with `@keyframes pulse` increasing scale and fading opacity). If using custom CSS, add it to the appropriate global or module stylesheet and reference the class from the dot element. Ensure the animation is smooth and non-jarring on standard refresh rates.
subtasks.testStrategy: Confirm in the browser that the dot appears as a small green circle and pulses continuously without stutter. Check that disabling animations (e.g., prefers-reduced-motion) behaves according to project standards if applicable.

subtasks.title: Wire StatusBadge text rendering and accessibility
subtasks.description: Ensure the component correctly renders dynamic status text and includes basic accessibility attributes for live status indication if needed.
subtasks.details: Bind the `status` prop directly into a text element (e.g., `{status}`). Consider wrapping the text in an element with `aria-label` or adding `aria-live="polite"` to the container if the status will change in real time. Ensure long status strings wrap or truncate according to design (e.g., `truncate` or `whitespace-nowrap` with max width) to prevent layout breaking. Avoid making the indicator focusable if it is purely informational.
subtasks.testStrategy: Test the component with several status strings of varying length, including very short and very long values, verifying layout behavior. Use a screen reader to confirm the status text is announced appropriately when the component mounts or updates, if `aria-live` is used.

subtasks.title: Integrate and verify StatusBadge usage within hero layout

Confirm that the component compiles in the existing Next.js/TypeScript setup, matches surrounding spacing, and respects the hero grid and dark theme. Update any barrel exports or index files if the project uses them for components under src/components/hero.
subtasks.testStrategy: Run the app and navigate to the hero section to confirm StatusBadge renders in the correct position with expected styling and animation. Check there are no TypeScript, ESLint, or runtime errors, and that snapshots or visual regression tests (if present) are updated or created for the new component.

tasks.title: Implement HeroVisual Component with Profile Image Styling

tasks.details: Build HeroVisual.tsx using Next.js Image component for optimization. Import profile image from assets/img directory. Apply professional styling with rounded rectangle container, 1px border resembling polaroid/data card. Add semi-transparent geometric shape (wireframe cube or code bracket SVG) behind image for depth. Implement grayscale or high-contrast filter to match dark theme. Include entrance animation: slide in from right (10px) with opacity fade 0->1, 100ms delay after text load.
tasks.testStrategy: Verify Next.js Image component loads and optimizes correctly. Test geometric background renders properly. Validate entrance animation timing and smoothness. Check image styling matches design specifications.

subtasks.title: Set up HeroVisual.tsx component structure and image import
subtasks.description: Create the HeroVisual.tsx React component file, import Next.js Image, and wire up the local profile image asset from the assets/img directory.

Import the profile image using a static import from assets/img (e.g., import profileImg from '@/assets/img/profile.jpg'). Define and export a functional HeroVisual component that returns a basic JSX structure with a wrapping div and an Image placeholder. Ensure the Image uses the imported src, has explicit width/height or fill with a sized parent, and includes alt text for accessibility.
subtasks.testStrategy: Render HeroVisual in a temporary test page and confirm the imported image loads correctly using the Next.js Image component without console or TypeScript errors.

subtasks.title: Implement framed container styling for profile image
subtasks.description: Apply layout and visual styling to create the rounded rectangle, polaroid/data-card-like frame around the profile image.
subtasks.details: Wrap the Image in a container div with Tailwind or CSS classes to create a rounded-rectangle frame (e.g., rounded-xl), 1px border, background matching the dark theme, and internal padding to resemble a polaroid/data card. Ensure the container uses relative positioning if needed, appropriate max-width constraints, and box-shadow or subtle glow if desired. Set object-fit (e.g., object-cover) and border-radius on the image if required so it fits nicely in the frame without distortion.
subtasks.testStrategy: Visually inspect in the browser to confirm the container appears as a professional card with a clear 1px border, correct rounding, and no overflow issues at different viewport sizes.

subtasks.title: Add geometric background element behind the profile image
subtasks.description: Create and position a semi-transparent geometric shape (e.g., SVG wireframe cube or code bracket) behind the framed profile image for depth.
subtasks.details: Add an additional decorative element behind the image frame, such as an inline SVG or imported SVG component. Position it using absolute positioning relative to the frame container (e.g., offset to top-right or bottom-left) and lower z-index so it sits behind the image frame. Apply semi-transparent styling via opacity or stroke color using theme tokens, and ensure it scales responsively without overlapping critical content. Keep the element purely decorative and non-interactive.
subtasks.testStrategy: Check in the browser that the geometric shape renders behind the image frame, maintains semi-transparency, and does not clip or overlap the image in an undesirable way across common screen sizes.

subtasks.title: Apply dark-theme image filters and visual treatment
subtasks.description: Configure grayscale or high-contrast image filters and ensure the visual treatment aligns with the dark IDE theme.
subtasks.details: Use CSS filters (e.g., filter grayscale, contrast, brightness) or Tailwind utility classes to apply grayscale or high-contrast treatment to the profile image so it matches the dark theme. Optionally add hover or subtle state changes if consistent with the design system. Ensure the filter does not reduce recognizability too much and works well with the background colors and frame styling. Verify the treatment looks consistent with other hero elements and design tokens from the theme configuration.
subtasks.testStrategy: Visually compare the filtered image against the surrounding dark theme to verify appropriate contrast and aesthetics, and confirm filters apply consistently in Chrome, Firefox, and Safari.

subtasks.title: Implement entrance animation for HeroVisual component
subtasks.description: Add a slide-in-from-right with fade-in entrance animation to the HeroVisual component, including a 100ms delay after text load.
subtasks.details: Define animation styles using CSS keyframes or Tailwind utilities (e.g., translate-x-2/3 and opacity transition). Configure the HeroVisual root container to start slightly translated on the x-axis (about 10px to the right) and opacity 0, then animate to x=0 and opacity 1. Set an animation delay of 100ms (via animation-delay or transition-delay) to approximate triggering after text load; if a parent prop or context exists, wire the animation start to that signal, otherwise use a simple mount-based animation. Ensure animation duration is smooth (e.g., 300â€“400ms) and respects user reduced-motion preferences if the project supports it.
subtasks.testStrategy: Observe the component mounting in the hero section and confirm it slides in from the right by ~10px with opacity fading from 0 to 1, starting roughly 100ms after the text, without jank or layout shift. Use dev tools to verify animation timing and easing.
